# 4.2 Covariance and correlation

## Definition
The **covariance** of two random variables $X$ and $Y$ is
$$
\text{cov}(X, Y) = E[(X-E[X])(Y-E[Y])].
$$

$X$ and $Y$ are **uncorrelated** if $\text{cov}(X,Y)=0$.

## Alternate form

$\text{cov}(X, Y) = E(XY) - E(X)E(Y)$.

## Covariance visualized

![Positively and negatively correlated patterns.](./images/f4-11.png){height=400 fig-alt="Positively and negatively correlated patterns."}

## Other results

For scalars $a$ and $b$:

- $\text{cov}(X, X) = \text{var}(X)$.
- $\text{cov}(X, aY + b) = a\text{cov}(X, Y)$.
- $\text{cov}(X, Y + Z) = \text{cov}(X, Y) + \text{cov}(X, Z)$.
- $\text{cov}(X, Y) = 0$ if $X$ and $Y$ are indepedent.

## Example

Let $X$ be a discrete uniform on $\{-1, 0, 1\}$. Let $Y = X^2$.

- Determine $\text{cov}(X, Y)$.
- Are $X$ and $Y$ independent?

## Example (cont)

## Correlation

The **correlation coefficient** of random variables $X$ and $Y$ is
$$
\rho(X, Y) = \frac{\text{cov}(X, Y)}{\sqrt{\text{var}(X)\text{var}(Y)}},
$$
when $\text{var}(X)>0$ and $\text{var}(Y)>0$.

## Interpretation

The correlation coefficient is a scaled version of covariance with $\rho\in[-1, 1]$.

If $\rho > 0$, then the values of $X - E(X)$ and $Y-E(Y)$ tend to have the same sign (deviate from the mean in the same direction).

If $\rho < 0$, then the deviations tend to have opposite signs.

## Example 4.14

Suppose that $X - E(X) = -[Y - E(Y)]$. Determine $\text{cor}(X, Y)$.

## Example 4.14 (cont)

# Variance of the Sum of Random Variables

## Variance of a sum

Let $X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n$ be a sequence of random variables with finite variance. Then
\begin{align}
\text{var}\left(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i \right) &= \sum_{i=1}^n \text{var}(X_i) + \sum_{\{(i,j)\mid i\neq j\}} \text{cov}(X_i, X_j)\\
&= \sum_{i=1}^n \text{var}(X_i) + 2 \sum_{i < j} \text{cov}(X_i, X_j).
\end{align}
